conversation.content: [trembling] I need to tell you something about the Cessna in bay three, the one you've been working on all week—something happened during my solo practice yesterday.
That plane's scheduled for a charter flight tomorrow morning with six passengers aboard, so whatever you're about to say better not involve damage. [sharp inhale]
[barely breathing] I took it up without clearance when you were at lunch, just wanted to log some extra hours, but I heard this grinding noise during descent.
[dangerously quiet] You flew my plane without authorization? The one I just spent forty hours rebuilding the hydraulic system on?
I know, I know.
No, you don't know—that grinding could be metal shavings in the hydraulics, could be stress fractures, could be a dozen things that kill people. [voice rising]
[desperate] That's why I'm here, telling you now instead of letting you find out during pre-flight, because I couldn't live with myself if something happened to those passengers.
You couldn't live with yourself? [bitter laugh] Six people could die because you wanted to play pilot, and you're worried about your conscience?
Please, just let me help you inspect it, let me pay for whatever needs fixing—I'll work here for free, anything, just [exhales] don't let that plane fly tomorrow.
[coldly methodical] Get me the maintenance log from the office, then we're pulling every single panel off that aircraft tonight.
You're not calling the FAA?
Not yet—depends what we find in that engine compartment and whether you're telling me everything about what happened up there. [pause] Was there smoke?
[quickly] No smoke, no visible damage, just that sound on descent, like metal on metal, lasted maybe ten seconds then stopped completely when I leveled out.
That's classic bearing failure in the elevator trim system, which means we're looking at a complete tail section inspection. [grimly] This is a twelve-hour job minimum.
[desperate whisper] I'll stay all night, I'll do whatever you need, I just couldn't let those people get on that plane without saying something.
Grab the inspection lights from storage and pray we find the problem before dawn, because if we don't, [exhales heavily] your pilot's license is the least of your worries.
[hollow] I know exactly what I've risked here—their lives, your reputation, everything—but keeping quiet would have been murder, wouldn't it?
Murder requires intent; what you did was criminally stupid, but at least you came forward. [softer] Now stop talking and start working—we have six lives to save.
[shaky exhale] Thank you for not just walking away or calling security—I know you have every right to destroy me over this.
[firmly] I'm not doing this for you—I'm doing it for the family that chartered that flight, but after tonight, you never come near my hangar again. Understood?

scenario: A pilot trainee confesses to an aircraft mechanic that they took an unauthorized flight in a plane scheduled for passengers the next day and heard concerning mechanical noises.
